transcript:
Patient: The behavioral activation has been a bit of a mixed bag. Some days, I'm able to do the activities I planned, and I notice a boost in my mood. But other days, I just don't have the energy or motivation to do anything.

Therapist: Fluctuations in energy and motivation are common experiences for people dealing with depression. It's great that you've noticed a boost in your mood on the days you're able to engage in activities. That's a good indication that behavioral activation can be an effective tool for you, even if it's not always easy to implement. Let's explore one of the days when you struggled to do the planned activities. What thoughts or feelings were going through your mind at that time?

Patient: I remember one day last week, I had planned to go for a walk in the park near my apartment. But when the time came, I just couldn't bring myself to get out of bed. I kept thinking, "What's the point? It's not going to make a difference anyway."

Therapist: That's a great example of how our thoughts can influence our behaviors. The thought "What's the point? It's not going to make a difference anyway" likely contributed to your decision to stay in bed instead of going for the walk. This is where the CBT triangle comes into play – our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are all interconnected. Can you identify what emotions you were experiencing along with that thought?

Patient: I was feeling pretty hopeless and apathetic. It felt like nothing I did would matter or make a difference in how I was feeling.

Therapist: Hopelessness and apathy are common emotions that can accompany depression. They can make it incredibly difficult to engage in activities, even when we know they might be beneficial for us. This is where the concept of opposite action can be helpful. Opposite action involves doing the opposite of what your emotions are telling you to do. In this case, it would mean going for the walk, even though you're feeling hopeless and apathetic. The idea is that by engaging in the opposite behavior, we can start to shift our emotions and thoughts over time.

Patient: That makes sense in theory, but it's hard to put into practice when I'm feeling so low.

Therapist: You're absolutely right. Opposite action is not an easy skill to implement, especially when you're dealing with intense emotions. That's why it's important to start small and be patient with yourself. You don't have to go from staying in bed all day to running a marathon. Maybe start with something as simple as sitting up in bed or walking to the kitchen to get a glass of water. The key is to gradually build up your ability to take opposite action, even in small ways.

Patient: I think I could try that. Maybe I could set a really small goal for myself on the days when I'm struggling, like just getting out of bed and sitting on the couch.

Therapist: That's a great idea, Emilio. Setting small, achievable goals is a fantastic way to start building momentum and challenging the thoughts and feelings that are keeping you stuck. Remember to give yourself credit for every small step you take, even if it feels insignificant in the moment. Every action, no matter how small, is a step in the right direction.

Patient: I'll try to keep that in mind. It's just hard not to get discouraged when I'm not able to do the things I want to do.

Therapist: It's completely understandable to feel discouraged at times. That's why it's so important to have self-compassion and recognize that progress isn't always linear. There will be ups and downs, but what matters is that you keep trying and don't give up on yourself. Speaking of progress, let's revisit the topic of social isolation that you brought up earlier. Can you tell me more about how that's been impacting you lately?
